questions.text: A Patient comes to the emergency room with vomiting and colicky abdominal pain. On further investigation evaluation the following Image was obtained. What is the Likely diagnosis based on the image given ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Horseshoe kidney is a congenital renal fusion anomaly in which the inferior poles of the kidneys are joined by an isthmus of renal parenchyma or fibrous tissue.
  • A key diagnostic feature seen here is the "shaking hand sign" on axial CT, where the medial aspects of both kidneys appear to touch or come close to each other, resembling a handshake-further supporting the diagnosis.
  • On axial CT, kidneys lie lower than normal, anterior to the aorta and IVC, with a visible midline connection.
  • Associated with urinary tract obstruction, renal calculi, and infections.

Explanation of other options:-

Ectopic kidney (Option A): This is a kidney located in an abnormal position, which might cause pain or urinary symptoms, but is less likely to present with the described acute symptoms and radiographic findings.

Pancake kidney (Option C): This is a rare condition where both kidneys are fused into a single mass in the pelvis or lower abdomen. It can cause similar symptoms due to obstruction or infection.

Meyer's dysplasia (Option D): This condition involves developmental abnormalities of the epiphyses and is not typically associated with acute abdominal symptoms or findings on abdominal imaging

questions.text: A 37-year-old Patient presented with complaints of Abdominal pain and Sterile Pyuria. The Following radiograph was taken, and findings are shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The Above Clinical findings and radiograph suggest a Putty kidney.
  • It is a sequela of genitourinary tuberculosis where the kidney becomes completely calcified and non-functioning.
  • On plain radiographs, it appears as a dense, shrunken, and often irregular calcified mass in the renal area.
  • Often associated with sterile pyuria and a history of chronic urinary symptoms.

Other Features of Renal TB:

  • Moth-eaten calyces (Earliest)
  • Phantom Calyx
  • Cement kidney
  • Loin pain

Explanation of other options:

NephroCalcinosis (Option B) refers to diffuse calcification of the renal parenchyma. It is typically associated with metabolic conditions such as hyperparathyroidism or medullary sponge kidney, and is less likely to cause sterile pyuria.

Calcified psoas abscess (Option C): This would typically present with flank paincand may show a mass effect on imaging

Staghorn Calculi (Option D): These are large kidney stones that take the shape of the renal pelvis and calyces. They can cause pain and hematuria but are less commonly associated with sterile pyuria. They would appear as large, branching calcifications on radiographs.

questions.text: Match the following.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritisis a chronic granulomatous inflammation of the kidneys.
    • On CT scan, there are hypoattenuating masses which represent the dilated calyces filled with pus and necrotic debris and are separated by the renal column of Bertini. With associated obstruction or infection.Bear paw sign on CT scan
    • Seen in elderly diabetics
    • Staghorn calculi/struvite calculi are seen
    • UTI -E. coli/proteus
    • Foamy lipid-laden macrophages are seen
  • Bear paw sign on CT scan
  • Thimble Bladderoccurs due to Fibrosis of the Bladder walls. It is seen that Tuberculosis of the Bladder.
  • Striated Nephrogram is seen in Acute Pyelonephritis.
  • Bladder Calcificationis seen in Bladder Schistosomiasis, resembling a Fetal Skull in X-ray. Squamous cell Carcinoma is a complication of chronic Bladder Schistosomiasis.

questions.text: Radiopaque density on an abdominal radiograph, which overlaps the vertebrae on a lateral radiograph, is suggestive of?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Renal stones overlap the vertebral shadows on a lateral radiograph, so they can be differentiated from gallstones.
  • It appears as a radiopaque density

Explanation of other options:

Gallstones (Option B) are anterior to the vertebral shadow on the lateral radiograph.

Mesenteric lymph nodes (Option C) are located along the Superior and Inferior Mesenteric arteries. Their calcification are an incidental finding and are not related to the vertebra.

Aortic calcifications (Option D) show common calcification in the thoracic cavity.

questions.text: Which of the following stones is not seen on KUB X-ray?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Uric acid, Lysine, Triamterene, Indinavir and Xanthine stones are radiolucent.

Radiolucent stones are not visible on plain X-ray imaging (KUB), making them harder to detect without advanced imaging.

questions.text: Swiss cheese nephrogram is seen in?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In ADPKD (Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease):

  • Bilaterally enlarged kidneys
  • Presence of multiple bilateral renal cysts
  • Contrast-enhanced imaging shows a Swiss cheese nephrogram pattern due to enhancement of normal intervening renal parenchyma with surrounding cysts.
  • Also shows the Spider-leg appearance of calyces on IVP.

Explanation of other options:

ARPKD (Option B):- Striated Nephrogram is seen in ARPKD and Pyelonephritis. ARPKD shows B/L enlarged kidneys with smooth contour. Cysts perpendicular to the renal cortex/renal capsule

Medullary Sponge kidney (Option C) shows Paint brush/Bouquet appearance because of cystic dilation of the collecting ducts.

choices.text: It is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner
CT scan is the first modality for its diagnosis
USG is used for screening in first-degree relatives

questions.text: A 52-year-old hypertensive male presented in the OPD with complaints of flank pain. A USG is advised and is given below. Identify the correct statement regarding the disease ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The ultrasound shows multiple anechoic cystic lesions in the kidney, suggestive of Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD).
  • ADPKD is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner. (Option A ruled out).
  • Ultrasonography is the first-line and most widely used screening tool in asymptomatic first-degree relatives.
  • While CT or MRI can be used for detailed evaluation, they are not the first-line tools for screening. (Option B ruled out)
  • ADPKD can occasionally be diagnosed antenatally if large cysts are present. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: What is the first-line imaging modality for evaluation of renal transplant dysfunction is :
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • According to the American College of Radiology appropriateness criteria for renal transplant dysfunction,US duplex Doppler is the first-line investigation.
  • Color doppler is used to evaluate the status of graft vessels and to detect any areas of focal stenosis or thrombosis.
  • Color doppler is also the primary diagnostic modality for identifying various vascular complications.
  • CT Scan, MRI and CECT (Options B, C & D ruled out) aren't first-line imaging studies for evaluating renal transplant dysfunction, whereas they can be used in further management.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the Emergency Department after blunt abdominal trauma. On evaluation rapidly decreasing hematocrit level on serial investigations was noted, and underwent a CECT abdomen, which is shown below. Identify the most likely cause for rapidly falling hematocrit levels.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given CECT image demonstrates a non-enhancing collection around the right kidney.
  • In the context of blunt trauma and falling hematocrit levels, this appearance is most suggestive of perirenal haemorrhage or hematoma.
  • The given image shows a collection around the right kidney, which is non-enhancing, and in the presence of a history of trauma, one should think of perirenal haemorrhage/ hematoma as the most probable diagnosis.

Explanation of other options:

Aortic dissection (Option B) shows the Tennis ball sign on CECT.

Extraperitoneal bladder rupture (Option C) shows Contrast extravasation in the perineum, giving a Molar tooth sign in cystography.

Intraperitoneal bladder (Option D) rupture shows contrast extravasation between Bowel loops and peritoneal folds.

choices.text: A systolic pressure gradient > 20 mm Hg across the lesion
Post-stenotic dilatation of the renal artery

questions.text: The most important sign of significance in renal artery stenosis on an angiogram is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The most important sign of the significance of renal artery stenosis on an angiogram is the Presence of collaterals.
  • The presence of collateral vessels on angiography suggests that the body has developed alternative pathways for blood flow due to a significant and prolonged reduction in blood flow from the main renal artery.
  • This indicates that the stenosis is severe enough to necessitate these collateral pathways, marking it as hemodynamically significant.

Explanation of other options:

A percentage diameter stenosis > 70% (Option A): While a significant degree of narrowing (greater than 70%) is important, it is not always conclusive on its own because it does not account for individual patient variability and compensatory mechanisms.

A systolic pressure gradient > 20 mm Hg across the lesion (Option C): This can indicate significant stenosis, but this measure is not typically obtained through standard angiography. It's more relevant in functional assessments using pressure wire studies during invasive procedures.

Post-stenotic dilatation of the renal artery (Option D): This is a sign that can accompany significant stenosis but is not the primary indicator of functional significance.

questions.text: A Young Female with uncontrolled HTN is evaluated, as part of the workup, the following image is obtained. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given DSA image demonstrates the classic "string of beads" appearance in the renal artery.
  • This pattern is characteristic of fibromuscular dysplasia, particularly the medial type, which is the most common variant.
  • It typically affects young to middle-aged women and causes secondary hypertension.

Explanation of other options:

Renal artery stenosis (Option B) affects the origin of the Renal artery. It is less likely to show a String of Beads appearance.

Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) (Option C) shows Multiple microaneurysms along the affected arteries (commonly seen in renal, hepatic, and mesenteric vessels). Segmental arterial stenosis alternating with dilatation, giving a "beaded" appearance

Infarcts or renal cortical scarring may be seen due to vascular occlusion

Renal artery aneurysms(Option D) cause thrombosis and infarction of the kidney, and will not show String of Beads appearance.

questions.text: Which of the following is a radiological sign of acute kidney disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Acute kidney disease is associated with an acute onset of oedema and inflammatory changes in the kidneys.
  • Imaging shows:
    • Enlarged kidneys
    • Increased cortical echogenicity
    • Perinephric free fluid, also referred to as the "kidney sweat sign", is suggestive of acute parenchymal insult.

Explanation of other options:

Small-sized kidney (Option A): More characteristic of chronic kidney disease, not acute.

Loss of corticomedullary differentiation (Option C): Can occur, but is not as specific as perinephric fluid.

Increased cortical echogenicity (Option D): Seen in both acute and chronic renal diseases; non-specific.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of the image below of IVU?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The IVU image shows a hydronephrotic kidney with ballooned calyces, suggestive of obstructive uropathy.
  • Common causes include PUJ obstruction, ureteric calculi, and ureteric strictures. (Options A, B and C ruled out)
  • Renal calyceal calculi do not typically produce this appearance; they are seen as radio-opacities without significant upstream dilatation unless causing obstruction.

questions.text: Central stellate scar is seen in which type of renal tumour?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Oncocytomas are the most common benign solid non-fat-containing renal mass.
  • Central scar is seen in oncocytomas.
  • This occurs due to the spoke wheel pattern of the feeding artery and the central areas of fibrous scarring, giving rise to a central scar-like appearance.
  • Stellate Scar in Pancreas is seen in Serous Cystadenoma.
  • Stellate Scar in the Liveris caused by Focal Nodular Hyperplasia and the fibrolamellar variant of HCC.

Explanation of other options:

Papillary renal cell carcinoma (Option B): Tends to show hypovascularity with peripheral location; central scar is not a feature.

Medullary renal cell carcinoma (Option C): A rare aggressive tumour typically seen in sickle cell trait; no central scar.

Clear cell carcinoma (Option D): The most common RCC subtype; often hypervascular with heterogeneous enhancement but lacks a central stellate scar.

questions.text: Identify the complication (black arrow) of renal cell carcinoma (white arrow) shown in the given CECT image?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given image shows a coronal CT scan of the abdomen.
  • The white arrow shows the renal mass, and the black arrow shows the IVC with internal non-enhancing areas within its lumen, suggestive of thrombosis.

Explanation of other options:

Hepatic metastasis (Option B) shows target appearance of multiple lesions in the liver parenchyma, whereas the given image shows a renal mass with non-enhancing areas in the IVC.

Renal haemorrhage (Option C) shows collection around the kidney, which is non-enhancing with a history of trauma, whereas the given image shows a renal mass with non-enhancing areas in the IVC.

Lung metastasis (Option D) shows a cannonball metastasis, whereas the given image shows a renal mass with non-enhancing areas in the IVC.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with a history of recurrent UTIs was brought to the paediatrician. As a part of the management protocol, an intravenous urography is done, which shows the following findings. What is the probable diagnosis based on the history and the radiography findings given?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given image shows a right-sided fishhook/S-shaped ureter, which is suggestive of Retrocaval Ureter.
  • The correct name is pre-ureteral vena cava.
  • Normally, in IVC development, the Right posterior cardinal vein regresses, and the right supracardinal vein forms into infra infra-renal vena cava.
  • In case of Retrocaval ureter, the right posterior cardinal vein fails to regress.

Explanation of other options:

VUR (Option A): Vesicoureteral reflux is characterised by retrograde flow of urine into the ureters/kidneys, usually demonstrated on MCU, not IVU.

Multicystic Dysplastic kidney (Option C) has no functioning renal tissue and is replaced by multiple cysts.

ADPKD (Option D):- Usually shows bilaterally enlarged kidneys with multiple cysts and often causes hypertension or renal failure in adults. It shows a spider leg appearance on a pyelogram.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with a history of chronic lower abdominal pain and increased frequency of urination. CT urography is performed and reveals bilateral smooth, narrowed, rigid ureters with a 'pipe stem' appearance. Pipe stem ureter is seen in?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Pipe stem ureteris a finding of tuberculosis of the ureter in which the ureter becomes shortened, rigid, inflexible and with a narrow lumen. This leads to a characteristic appearance of the pipe stem ureter.

Image findings in renal TB

Kidney

  • Moth-eaten calyces (Earliest)
  • Putty kidney
  • Cement kidney
  • Phantom calyx - due to infundibular stenosis

In ureter

  • Tortuous appearance/beaded/corkscrew appearance
  • Kerr kink (because of fibrosis)

On cystoscopy

  • Golf hole ureteral orifice

In the bladder

  • Thimble bladder

Explanation of other options:

Schistosomiasis (Option A): Bladder Calcification is seen in Bladder Schistosomiasis, resembling Fetal Skull.

Squamous cell Carcinoma is a complication of chronic Bladder Schistosomiasis.

Proteus infection (Option C) results in the formation of Staghorn calculi/struvite calculi, Pipestem Ureter is not seen with this.

Xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis (Option D) shows Bearpaw sign. It is associated with renal parenchymal destruction, not a smooth, narrowed ureteric appearance.

questions.text: Match the following;
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Transitional Cell Carcinoma of Ureter(TCC) typically shows a "goblet sign", where the mass causes a dilated ureter proximal to the tumour, giving a goblet-shaped contour.
  • B. Ureterocele presents with a "cobra or adder head appearance" due to the ballooning of the distal ureter into the bladder.
  • C. Retrocaval ureter shows a "fish hook sign" on imaging, due to medial deviation and kinking of the ureter behind the IVC.
  • D. Retroperitoneal fibrosis causes "maiden waist deformity" by causing bilateral medial deviation and tapering of the ureters.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the paediatrician with complaints of fever and recurrent urinary tract infections. To evaluate for possible vesicoureteric reflux (VUR), which of the following is the investigation of choice?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) representsthe retrograde flow of urine from the bladder to the upper urinary tract, so to assess the retrograde flow, a Micturating cystourethrogram is used.
  • An MCU involves the insertion of a catheter into the bladder and the instillation of contrast material into the bladder.
  • Imaging is then performed while the child urinates (micturates), allowing visualisation of the bladder, urethra, and any reflux of contrast into the ureters and kidneys.
  • MCU is considered the gold standard for diagnosing VUR.
  • Micturating Cystourethrogram (MCU) is used to assess the posterior urethra. It is the investigation of choice for Vesicoureteric Reflux (VUR)and Posterior Urethral Valve (PUV).
  • Retrograde Urethrogram (RGU) is used to assess the anterior urethra. It is the investigation of choice for Urethral strictureand Urethral injury.
  • IOC for PUV - antenatal USG [shows keyhole appearance] > micturating cystourethrogram

Micturating cystourethrogram

  • IOC for PUJ obstruction- Diuretic renogram

Diuretic renogram

Explanation of other options;

Antegrade IVP (Option A): Antegrade intravenous pyelography (IVP) involves the direct injection of contrast into the renal pelvis or ureter via a percutaneous nephrostomy tube. While it can provide valuable information about upper urinary tract anatomy and function, it is not typically used as the primary investigation for VUR.

Retrograde IVP (Option B): Retrograde intravenous pyelography (IVP) involves the injection of contrast into the bladder via a catheter, followed by imaging to visualise the urinary tract. While it can demonstrate reflux of contrast into the ureters and kidneys, it is not typically used as the primary investigation for VUR.

Cystoscopy (Option D): Cystoscopy involves the insertion of a flexible or rigid tube with a camera into the bladder to visualise the bladder and urethra. While cystoscopy can provide valuable information about the bladder and urethra, it is not typically used as the primary investigation for VUR.

choices.text: Reflux into pelvis and Calyces without dilatation
Mild to moderate dilatation of the Ureter
Moderate Ureteral tortuosity and dilatation of the Pelvis and calyces
Gross dilatation of the Ureter, pelvis and calyces

questions.text: Identify the Features of Grade 4 VUR?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) represents the retrograde flow of urine from the bladder to the upper urinary tract.

  • Grade 4 VUR is characterised by moderate dilatation of the renal pelvis and calyces with blunting of the fornices and mild to moderate tortuosity of the ureter.
  • It represents a more advanced stage of reflux with the beginning distortion of the renal collecting system.
  • This stage is commonly seen in children with recurrent urinary infections and can predispose to renal scarring if not treated early.

Grades VUR;

  • Grade I- Into a nondilated ureter.
  • Grade II- reflux into the pelvis and calyces without dilation. (Option A ruled out)
  • Grade III-Mild to moderate dilation of the ureter, renal pelvis, and calyces with minimal blunting of the fornices. (Option B ruled out )
  • Grade IV-Moderate ureteral tortuosity and dilation of the pelvis and calyces
  • Grade V- Gross dilation of the ureter, pelvis, and calyces; loss of papillary impressions; and ureteral tortuosity. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 50-year-old male came with lower Urinary tract symptoms, and X-ray and CT-KUB were done and showed the following pattern of calcification. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given image shows Circumferential calcification of the Bladder resembling a Fetal Skull in late stages of Bladder Schistosomiasis. It is also called "Bilharzia of the bladder".
  • Schistosomiasis (especially caused by Schistosoma haematobium) is a parasitic infection endemic in certain regions. It leads to chronic granulomatous inflammation, fibrosis, and ultimately calcification of the bladder wall.
  • The pathognomonic imaging finding is curvilinear or ring-like calcification of the bladder wall seen on X-ray and CT.
  • Long-standing infection can predispose to squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder.
  • Squamous cell Carcinomais a complication of chronic Bladder Schistosomiasis.

Explanation of other options:

Urinary Bladder Carcinoma (Option A) shows irregular filling defects, wall thickening, mass lesions,

Tuberculosis (Option C): Thimble Bladder ( Small, contracted bladder with thickened, irregular walls due to Fibrosis of Bladder) is commonly seen with Tuberculosis of the Bladder.

Neurogenic Bladder(Option D): Christmas tree bladder' is a specific term used to describe the cystographic appearance of a neurogenic bladder, where the bladder wall shows extensive trabeculation and outpouchings (diverticula), resembling the shape of a Christmas tree.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with a history of recurrent Urinary tract infections. A Cystography was advised, and it revealed the following findings. What is the probable diagnosis based on it?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given image shows a pine cone or a christmas tree appearance.
  • It shows a pointed and elongated bladder seen in a neurogenic bladder.
  • This is seen in neurogenic bladder with increased sphincter tone.
  • It is seen in neurological injury of suprasacral lesions (S2-S4) or epiconal lesions (in and around S2-S4).
  • It may also be seen in bladder obstruction of non-neurologic cause.
  • UTIs result from the incomplete voiding of the bladder.

Explanation of other options:

Urinary Bladder Carcinoma (Option A) shows irregular filling defects, wall thickening, mass lesions,

Schistosomiasis (Option C): radiological findings include, Thickened bladder wall, calcifications, and an irregular outline. Fetal skull-like calcification of the bladder wall is seen in Schistosomiasis (fibrosis and calcification within the bladder wall)

Thimble Bladder (Option D): On radiology, small, contracted bladder with thickened, irregular walls, due to Fibrosis of Bladder walls and is commonly seen with Tuberculosis of the Bladder.

questions.text: Pear shaped bladder is seen in all of the following conditions except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Neurogenic Bladder shows the Pine cone/ Christmas tree bladder; the Pear-shaped bladder is not seen in this case.

A pear-shaped bladder is seen in :

  • Pelvic abscess (Option B ruled out)
  • Pelvic Hematoma (Option C ruled out)
  • Pelvic Lipomatosis
  • Symmetric Pelvic Lymphadenopathy (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A patient presented with hematuria and a poor stream of urine for the last 1 month. He was advised to undergo an X-ray, which is shown below. Identify the most probable diagnosis.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The X-ray image shows a well-defined, round radiopaque shadow within the pelvic region, corresponding to the anatomical location of the urinary bladder, which is characteristic of a vesical (bladder) calculus.
  • Clinical features such as hematuria and poor stream of urine also support bladder outlet obstruction, often caused by a large bladder stone.

Explanation of other options:

Ureteric calculi (Option A) are seen in the path of the ureter and are not seen in the pelvis.

Urinary tract infections (Option C) presents with fever, pain or burning micturition, cloudy urine and Frequent micturition.

Urethral calculus (Option D) would be seen further down in the pelvic region, while a Bladder stone is seen in the pelvis.

choices.text: Hypoechoic spermatic cord with reduced vascularity
Hyperechoic spermatic cord with reduced vascularity

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with scrotal pain, swelling and a few episodes of fever. On examination of elevating the testis, the pain is reduced. What will be the USG finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The examination findings point to a possibility of epididymitis, which is an inflammation of the epididymis
  • In inflammation of the epididymis, there is increased vascularity (because of an increase in blood flow) and it appears hypoechoic and bulky(due to oedema).
  • Prehn's sign: A diagnostic technique that assesses the cause of testicular painby lifting the scrotum and observing any changes in pain.
  • A positive Prehn's signindicates that pain is relieved when the scrotum is elevated, which suggests epididymitis.
  • A negative Prehn's sign, where pain is not relieved by lifting the scrotum, suggests testicular Torsion. Vascularity may be compromised in Testicular Torsion.
  • Whirlpool sign on USG is seen in Testicular Torsion.

Explanation of other options:

Hyperechoic epididymis with increased vascularity (Option B): Acute inflammation leads to hypoechogenicity, not hyperechogenicity.

Hypoechoic spermatic cord with reduced vascularity (Option C): Suggestive of torsion or ischemia, not epididymitis.

Hyperechoic spermatic cord with reduced vascularity (Option D): Also more likely in torsion; not consistent with findings in epididymitis.

questions.text: For PIRADS scoring, which of the following sequences of MRI are used?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The Prostate Imaging Reporting and Data System (PI-RADS) is used to assess the likelihood of clinically significant prostate cancer on multiparametric MRI.
  • It relies on three key MRI sequences:
    • T2-weighted imaging (T2WI) for zonal anatomy
    • Diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) for tissue cellularity and tumour detection
    • Dynamic contrast-enhanced imaging (DCE) for vascularity patterns in lesions
  • Prostate Imaging Reporting and Data System (PI-RADS) scoring is used in prostate imaging for finding the probability of having a malignancy in a suspicious lesion.
  • It is based on the MRI technique. This is based on 3 sequences- T2WI, DYNAMIC CONTRAST, DWI.

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with bladder voiding difficulties after urethral instrumentation. He was advised to undergo an RGU, which is shown below. Identify the diagnosis.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given image is of RGU (Retrograde urethrogram), which shows thinning of the urethra at various levels, and the history of instrumentation is suggestive of urethral stricture.
  • RGU is used for evaluating the anterior urethra (Penile + Bulbar )

MCU is used for evaluating the posterior urethra(Membranous + prostatic)

Explanation of other options:

Bladder diverticulum (Option B) is an outpouching from the bladder wall, whereas the given RGU image shows the stricture.

Urethral injury (Option C): In case of urethral injury, contrast is extravasated into the perineum, and no contrast in the bladder is suggestive of complete urethral injury.

In Urethral Diverticulum (Option D), a sac forms along the Urethra, whereas the given RGU image shows the presence of urethral stricture.

questions.text: A 44-year-old male patient presented to the OPD with complaints of weight loss and hematuria. He has been working in the Paint industry for the past 15 years. He underwent an IVP study, which is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given IVP image shows a filling defect in the urinary bladder, shown by the arrow. The whole urinary bladder is opacified by contrast except the area of the filling defect.
  • This clinical feature and the given history are highly suggestive of urinary bladder carcinoma, which is endophytic and grows into the urinary bladder.
  • The paint industry uses many chemicals, including Benzidine is one of them which causes Bladder Cancer.

Explanation of other options:

Neurogenic Bladder (Option A): shows Pine cone / Christmas tree bladder,

Renal calculus (Option C) appears inside the kidney, appearing as opaque (white) densities on X-rays.

VUR (Option D): Urine flows retrogradely to the kidney, which leads to dilation of the ureter and calyces. Whereas the given IVP image shows a filling defect in the urinary bladder, suggestive of Bladder carcinoma.
